sign down here um there is uh there's this there's this popular
uh technique that we you know all embedded developers do this from time to time we do bit banging which means we
just we uh have some code that says raise the voltage on a pin and then lower the voltage on a pin and then we
you know do that a whole bunch of times with little time timers in between and often times the timers are really stupid
like just looping over some knops or something and and um and uh this
technique of bit banging is very useful because it's extremely flexible um when you're developing it
for the first time but when you want to go back and maintain code or change make
it compatible with other targets um it's not necessarily the most flexible thing
if you want to change the speed that it's running at you know you have an interface that's running at 500 khz and you want to run it at 2 megahertz or
something uh it may not be really obvious and easy to do that if it's bitbang code um and uh there are
peripherals there are little add-on components inside microcontrollers that do a lot of
these kinds of functions for you this particular one is an i squ c interface from good fet we're bit banging i squ c
with good fit even though the chip has a special purpose I squ C peripheral built in we're just not using the i squ c

to the victim or the target host and in between the two there's a
one megabit per second serial link to control that USB controller so it's this tremendous

thing that good good Fett was was designed to emulate was a debugger from Texas Instruments that was called a fet
and it wasn't a flash emulation tool but somewhere back in the L in the lineage there were debuggers
that were known as flash emulation tools and the idea is that I mean this goes this technique goes back at at least to
the like 80s uh the idea is that you have uh some kind of um microcontroller
or microprocessor and how do you debug it how do you like do like a single step
through code and stuff like that and uh a popular technique in those days was to
uh actually uh like remove the external uh storage the program storage ROM or
Flash and like wire in a debugger which emulates that storage and uh that
technique was used for debuggers for a long time and so then when they started making debuggers that worked in a
different way they sometimes used the same terminology to refer to it even though it wasn't a flash emulation tool
so just FYI that's where flash emulation tool come or that's where the name fet comes from interestingly one thing we
can do with gra Fett that like uh would be difficult to do with
with the Texas Instruments fet uh is we can emulate flash I haven't tried it but
we could totally do that so that's not its primary function but we could do that uh and we have a bunch of add-on
